36C5C455CF0540EA9928AA1BE8A67FD1.description: Using various sources, formulate an argument to distinguish the most influential factors that shaped the early history of the United States.

EB82349EDE5A4DED800BB98464CB024C.description: Describe why the inclusion of the Bill of Rights was needed for ratification.

9C3134F872934E1883978850B225737E.description: Explain why the Constitution was written, describe the issues that were addressed in the Constitution, and describe the rights found in the First, Second, Third, and Fourth Amendments.

9DBA14F6622348FC88D39E210449284B.description: Describe the powers of the national government and state governments under the Articles of Confederation.

32383174E80148439F51FAF7FD84A090.description: Explain the significance of the Treaty of Paris.

4F2F8A1DAD894EAE891C9A7DFAB5F6BE.description: Identify and describe the major battles of the American Revolution, and compare the roles of various groups in helping shape the outcome of the war.

012574BFB1D24EE095703387AC807918.description: Describe the advantages and disadvantages of each side during the American Revolution.

F50BA1DCB388406797E171DC70E9A884.description: Identify a problem that confronted people in the colonies, identify alternative choices for addressing the problem with possible consequences, and describe the course of action taken.

F37CBE23E9DE4F44839C69C0205D0AEA.description: Examine the role of Catholics during the time of colonization and the American Revolution, including the role of Charles Carroll as the only Catholic to sign the Declaration of Independence.

1EF4F618E64042298A3EA506F846DC5A.description: Identify the role that key individuals played in leading the colonists to revolution, including George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Benjamin Franklin Patrick Henry, Samuel Adams, John Adams, and Thomas Paine, and examine their lives for examples of virtue or vice.

9270ADA2D45F4B8B91561E418FF5FCD3.description: Use the Declaration of Independence to explain why the colonists wanted to separate from Great Britain and why they believed they had the right to do so.

6ECD22051BB447098B1D46C2E39417D0.description: Describe the causes and effects of events such as the Stamp Act, Boston Tea Party, the Intolerable Acts, and the Boston Massacre.

5EBDDF7F361E47F1B007A856D1ACC233.description: Describe the role of the French and Indian War, how British policy toward the colonies changed over time, and the colonial dissatisfaction with the new policy.

BAF3B141C3CB468AA13A948345F37527.description: Identify the major political, economic, and ideological reasons for the American Revolution.

8D5D4A1CBA1744D5AFE0AEF63EE8C802.description:
Describe colonial life in America from the perspectives of at least three different
groups of people (i.e. women, slaves, indentured servants, American Indians, wealthy landowners, merchants, free Africans).

BA9124F2DFC3405EA80A25CED61378EF.description: Describe the life of enslaved Africans and free Africans in the American colonies, and how they drew upon their African past and adapted elements of new cultures to develop a distinct African American culture.

75CBF5E865AB494A953A59EE50AE1240.description: Describe Triangular Trade including trade routes, the people and goods that were traded, the Middle Passage, its impact on life in Africa, and its impact on human dignity and the common good.

63BF01927937401CB596762ADB51C7D9.description: Describe developments in the Middle Colonies including the growth of economies, the Dutch settlements in New Netherlands, the Quaker settlement in Pennsylvania, and the subsequent English takeover of the Middle Colonies, and the immigration patterns leading to ethnic diversity.

B7BDD50B472B43F0BD983A5F6FB31BF6.description: Describe developments in the New England colonies, including patterns of settlement and control, the growth of agricultural and non-agricultural economies, the use of town meetings and colonial legislatures, and religious tensions in Massachusetts that led to the establishment of other colonies in New England.

1623654F64AB492F9E64D5E27D7D35EB.description: Describe developments in the Southern colonies; including patterns of settlement and control, the establishment of Jamestown, the role of Catholics in Maryland, and the use of one-crop economics, colonial representative assemblies, and slavery.

F4F8615BB49A420D8F12177A41BAE195.description: Describe the Columbian Exchange and its impact on Europeans, American Indians, and Africans.

2225C3725D954BCFBEA0326D7A0EA519.description: Examine the role of Catholic missionaries in the eras of American exploration and colonization.

75C708A1BC424D78AA1CF5438653EED7.description: Compare the different approaches used by the British and French in their interactions with American Indians and explain the cultural impact on American Indians of each approach.

31412ACB53B8406CB59DE85EF62412DE.description: Use primary and secondary sources to describe the convergence of European, American Indians, and Africans in North America after 1492 from the various perspectives of these three groups, considering the Catholic social teaching of solidarity and promotion of peace.

09CDDFF650854E1EA62185207E607BFB.description: Describe the life and cultural development of people living in western Africa before the 16th century, including their economic and family structures, and the growth of states, towns, and trade; and compare the motivating values of those societies to those of Catholic teaching.

F1D75DABEE794FFEA099874A57900162.description: Use case studies of individual explorers or stories of life in Europe to describe the goals, obstacles, motivations, and consequences for European exploration and colonization of the Americas; and compare the motivating values of those societies and individuals with those of Catholic social teaching.

52AA40CD716F420A9960C09F64C192CE.description: Describe American Indian life prior to European exploration of America, including their government, family structures, use of trade, and view on property ownership and land use; and compare the motivating values of those societies to those of Catholic teaching.

14A97A296FC04A76B5FEF75CCADB5F50.description: Use maps to locate peoples living in North America before European exploration.

3ADBACC3911143B79DD680CFD2730CBD.description: Pursue peace and truth through the demonstration of respect for the attributes of various cultures, as we are called to be one human family on earth.

5ADC8A3956484D71B564172DBA633771.description: Apply Catholic virtues and democratic principles when working with others.
